_note: Starter set for Phase 0 scaffold. Full extraction from fasta_analysis_app_final.py TRANSLATIONS['en'] is Step 3.
sidebar_large_dataset_warning: Large dataset: Sample mode enabled for responsive filtering
page_under_construction: This page is under active development.
upload_instruction: Upload one or more FASTA files (.fasta, .fa, .gz, .zip)
upload_colab_unavailable: Google Colab Drive not available in this environment.
hitl_lasso_instruction: Drag to highlight zones for extraction
hitl_lasso_zone_warning: No sequences found in selected zone.
hitl_select_peaks_header: Select peaks to include in analysis:
download_tooltip_fasta: Download representative sequences in FASTA format.
download_tooltip_csv: Download sequence metadata as a CSV table.
download_tooltip_json: Download a JSON snapshot of filter thresholds and timestamps applied.
download_tooltip_zip: Download FASTA, CSV, and methodology snapshot bundled as a ZIP archive.
export_log_tooltip: Download a log of all filtering operations and thresholds applied this session.
obs_no_data: Upload and activate a dataset to view the observatory.
perf_large_warning: Large dataset ({count} seqs): Pre-clustering for performance.
error_no_active_df: No active dataset. Please upload and activate sequences first.
error_no_filtered_df: No filtered results yet. Apply filters first.
error_empty_selection: No sequences match the current selection.
error_genetic_timeout: Genetic analysis timeout â€” falling back to chronological sampling.
filter_quality_caption: Remove short, ambiguous, or duplicate sequences from the active dataset.
filter_min_length_help: Remove sequences shorter than this threshold. Typical HA segment: 1,600â€“1,800 bp.
filter_max_n_run_help: Remove sequences containing a run of N (unknown bases) at least this long.
filter_dedup_help: Remove identical sequences. 'seq+subtype' keeps one representative per subtype.
filter_std_headers_help: Trim leading/trailing whitespace from isolate names.
filter_header_comp_caption: Build per-field rules that are combined into a single vectorized boolean mask.
filter_accession_caption: Keep only sequences matching a specific list of EPI_ISL accession IDs.
filter_accession_input: Paste EPI_ISL accession IDs (one per line or comma-separated):
filter_accession_help: Enter accession IDs such as EPI_ISL_123456. Lines are stripped and matched exactly.
hitl_caption: Intelligently reduce your dataset to phylogenetically representative sequences.
hitl_strategy_help: Choose an automated or manual strategy for selecting representative sequences across time.
hitl_chron_desc: Automatically classifies dataset lifespan and applies weekly, monthly, or quarterly sentinel sampling.
hitl_volume_desc: Uses scipy wave detection to identify epidemic peaks and extract one representative per wave crest and trough.
hitl_checklist_desc: Review detected peaks and manually select which periods to include.
hitl_no_peaks: No peaks detected with current sensitivity. Try lowering sensitivity.
hitl_lasso_desc: Draw a selection box on the epidemic curve chart to extract sequences from chosen weeks.
hitl_lasso_caption: Chart uses aggregated weekly counts â€” never raw sequence dots.
hitl_lasso_chart_title: Weekly Sequence Counts â€” drag to select
hitl_lasso_no_selection: Drag on the chart above to select weeks, then click Extract.
hitl_no_dates: No dated sequences in this dataset.
hitl_checkpoints_desc: Enter specific time points; sequences within a tolerance window will be extracted.
hitl_checkpoints_input: Enter checkpoint dates (one per line, YYYY-MM or YYYY-MM-DD):
hitl_checkpoints_help: Each date defines a target; sequences within Â±tolerance are included.
hitl_checkpoints_tolerance_help: 1W = Â±7 days, 2W = Â±14 days, 1M = Â±30 days from each checkpoint.
download_fasta_help: Download representative sequences in FASTA format.
download_csv_help: Download sequence metadata as a CSV table (sequences excluded).
download_methodology_help: Download a JSON record of all filter operations and thresholds applied this session.
obs_showing_active: Showing full active dataset â€” apply filters in Filter Lab to refine.
welcome_tagline: The next-generation platform for FASTA-based viral surveillance at genomic scale
welcome_message: Upload your GISAID FASTA exports and instantly unlock epidemic curve analysis, phylogenetic sub-sampling, multi-dimensional filtering, and one-click export bundles â€” all without leaving your browser.
welcome_formats: Supported: .fasta Â· .fa Â· .fasta.gz Â· .zip (max 50,000 sequences per session)
welcome_step1_desc: Upload GISAID FASTA files and activate a working dataset
welcome_step2_desc: Apply quality filters, deduplication, and HITL smart sub-sampling
welcome_step3_desc: Visualize distributions, epidemic curves, and cross-tab charts
welcome_step4_desc: Export FASTA, CSV, methodology JSON, or per-clade ZIP bundles
welcome_feat1_desc: Parse-once caching with vectorized boolean masks â€” sub-second filtering on 10K+ sequences
welcome_feat2_desc: Full English / Russian UI with Rospotrebnadzor-aligned terminology
welcome_feat3_desc: 5 bridging strategies: auto sentinel, volume peaks, checklist, visual lasso, time checkpoints
welcome_feat4_desc: Adaptive pre-clustering and sample-mode for datasets beyond 10,000 sequences
welcome_cta_desc: Go to Workspace â†’ upload FASTA files â†’ click Activate
welcome_info_1: Sequences must be in GISAID pipe-header format: name|type|subtype|segment|location|host|date
welcome_info_2: Non-GISAID headers are auto-detected and cleaned on upload
welcome_info_3: All processing is local â€” no sequences are transmitted to external servers
welcome_info_4: Reset the session at any time to clear all data and start fresh
welcome_guide_body:
**Step 1 â€” Upload:** Navigate to **Workspace** (ğŸ“) and upload your FASTA file(s). Supported: `.fasta`, `.fa`, `.gz`, `.zip`. Then click **Activate Selected Dataset**.

**Step 2 â€” Filter:** Go to **Filter Lab** (ğŸ§¬). Apply quality filters (min length, max N-run), header filters, and optionally use HITL Smart Sampling to reduce your dataset to phylogenetically representative sequences.

**Step 3 â€” Analyze:** Visit **Analytics** (ğŸ“Š) to generate distribution, temporal, stacked, or epidemic curve charts. Customize color palettes with the built-in Palette Studio.

**Step 4 â€” Export:** Open **Export** (ğŸ“‹) to download FASTA, CSV, methodology JSON, or a complete ZIP bundle. Use Split & Export to generate per-group FASTA files automatically.
analytics_same_category_warning: Category 1 and Category 2 must be different fields.
analytics_no_seq_for_dna: No sequence data found for DNA color generation.
analytics_no_data: No data available for this field/interval combination.
analytics_download_html_help: Download this chart as a standalone interactive HTML file (Plotly CDN-linked).
export_quick_caption: Download the current export dataset in multiple formats with a single click.
export_split_caption: Group sequences by any metadata field and generate one FASTA file per group, bundled as a ZIP archive.
export_split_field_help: Choose which metadata column to use as the grouping key.
export_split_large_warning: âš  {n} groups Ã— {seqs} sequences â€” this may take a moment.
export_split_more: {extra} more groups â€” use ZIP for all
export_accession_caption: Extract all EPI_ISL accession IDs from the current export dataset.
export_accession_help: Download a plain-text list of all unique EPI_ISL accession IDs, one per line.
analytics_completeness_label: % sequences with date + subtype + host filled
analytics_no_length_col: No sequence_length column in this dataset.
filter_reset_btn: â†© Reset All Filters (Restore Active Dataset)
filter_no_rules_info: No rules added yet â€” add at least one rule above, then apply.
filter_header_success: Header filters applied â€” {n} sequences retained.
nav_go_filterlab: ğŸ§¬ Go to Filter Lab â†’
filter_acc_success: Accession filter applied â€” {n} sequences matched from {total} provided.
timeline_caption: Track the persistence of identical sequences across time
timeline_mission_header: This tool answers: How long did specific viral clones survive in circulation?
timeline_use_this_when: Use this page when you want to:
timeline_use1: Track the first and last occurrence of identical sequences
timeline_use2: Build timelines showing sequence persistence across months or years
timeline_use3: Remove temporal duplicates while preserving evolutionary anchors
timeline_use4: Study overwintering survival of specific viral clones
timeline_use_refinery_instead: Use Sequence Refinery instead if you want to:
timeline_refinery1: Clean datasets by quality metrics (length, ambiguous bases)
timeline_refinery2: Sample outbreak patterns at population level
timeline_refinery3: Extract representatives based on epidemic curves or HITL selection
timeline_no_data: No dataset loaded. Upload a FASTA file in the Workspace page first.
timeline_no_sequence_col: Dataset has no 'sequence' column. Cannot compute molecular identity.
timeline_all_singletons: All sequences are unique â€” no duplicate clusters detected.
timeline_min_cluster_help: Hide singleton and small clusters to focus on persistent clones
timeline_rep_logic_label: When multiple identical sequences exist in a checked month, extract the:
timeline_rep_logic_help: This selection logic applies to all intermediate (non-anchor) months
timeline_identity_guarantee_body: Each row represents one unique molecular clone. When you check a month box, the tool searches for sequences in that month identical to the anchor. If multiple identical copies exist, it extracts the best representative based on your quality settings. This guarantees perfect molecular continuity: First â†’ Selected months â†’ Last.
timeline_no_date_col: No 'collection_date' column found. Date-based timeline matrix is unavailable.
timeline_matrix_how1: Each row = one unique molecular clone (identical sequences)
timeline_matrix_how2: First and Last occurrences are automatically selected (locked anchors)
timeline_matrix_how3: Check boxes for intermediate months you want to sample
timeline_matrix_how4: The tool extracts the best representative from each checked month
timeline_no_clusters: No clusters with â‰¥ {n} sequences found. Try lowering the minimum cluster size.
timeline_showing_clusters: Showing {n} persistent sequence clusters (minimum cluster size: {threshold})
timeline_too_many_clusters: Large number of clusters. Consider increasing the minimum cluster size for better performance.
timeline_month_col_help: Check to extract a representative sequence from {month}
timeline_no_sequence_for_extraction: Sequence column not available for FASTA extraction.
timeline_configure_matrix_first: Configure the timeline matrix above, then click Generate Preview.
timeline_extraction_success: âœ… {n} sequences extracted and saved as filtered dataset.
timeline_no_months_selected: No months are selected. Check some boxes in the matrix above.
timeline_sidebar_tip: ğŸ’¡ Tip: After extraction, visit Analytics to visualize your curated timeline.
rsv_support_note: This tool works with RSV A/B, Influenza A/B, SARS-CoV-2, and any FASTA with standard GISAID-style pipe-delimited headers.
use_case_tip_upload: ğŸ’¡ Tip: Upload your RSV or influenza FASTA, then activate it in Workspace to begin.
use_case_tip_filter: ğŸ’¡ Tip: Use Sequence Refinery to set minimum length (â‰¥ 14,000 bp for RSV genome) and remove sequences with > 5% ambiguous bases.
use_case_tip_timeline: ğŸ’¡ Tip: Use Molecular Timeline to track if the same RSV clone persisted across two consecutive seasons.
use_case_tip_analytics: ğŸ’¡ Tip: Use Analytics â†’ Stacked Bar to compare RSV-A vs RSV-B prevalence by month.
workspace_select_activate: Select file(s) to activate (select multiple to merge):
workspace_activated_success: âœ… Activated {n:,} sequences from {files} file(s) into active dataset.
workspace_url_no_seqs: No sequences found at that URL.
timeline_singletons_included: â†ª {n} singleton/rare sequences (clusters < {total} threshold) auto-included as First+Last anchors.
